title: Miracles and Mercy
shortSummary: Matthew 9 showcases Jesus’ authority to forgive sins and perform miracles, affirming His identity as the Son of Man. The chapter highlights His compassion for the sick and sinners, His call of Matthew, and His teaching on mercy over ritual, emphasizing the abundant harvest and the need for laborers.
timeline: c. AD 27-30 - Early Ministry of Jesus in Galilee

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of Man who teaches, heals, forgives sins, and calls sinners to repentance throughout the chapter.

keyCharacters.name: Matthew
keyCharacters.description: A tax collector called by Jesus to follow Him, illustrating Jesus’ outreach to sinners.

keyCharacters.name: The Pharisees
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who question Jesus’ association with sinners and accuse Him of blasphemy and demonic power.

keyCharacters.name: The Sick and Disabled
keyCharacters.description: Various individuals healed by Jesus, demonstrating His power and compassion.

definitions.definition: A term used in the Bible to describe paralysis or a debilitating sickness affecting movement.
Tax collectors who were often despised by Jews for collaborating with Roman authorities and seen as sinners.
The act of speaking irreverently about God or claiming divine attributes unlawfully, considered a grave sin.
A metaphor for Jesus representing joy and presence; His absence will bring mourning, used to explain fasting.
A metaphor illustrating the incompatibility of Jesus’ new teachings with old religious traditions.

outline.heading: Jesus Forgives and Heals the Paralytic
outline.description: Jesus demonstrates His authority to forgive sins and heal physical ailments, provoking controversy among the scribes but leading the crowds to glorify God.

outline.heading: Calling of Matthew and Jesus’ Fellowship with Sinners
outline.description: Jesus calls Matthew, a tax collector, to follow Him and explains His mission to call sinners to repentance rather than the self-righteous.

outline.heading: Questions about Fasting and New Teachings
outline.description: Jesus addresses questions about fasting by using metaphors of the bridegroom, new cloth, and new wine to illustrate the newness of His kingdom.

outline.heading: Miracles of Healing: Daughter of the Ruler and Woman with Issue of Blood
outline.description: Jesus responds to faith by raising a ruler’s daughter from death and healing a woman who touched His garment, showing His power over sickness and death.

outline.heading: Healing the Blind and the Dumb, and Opposition from Pharisees
outline.description: Jesus heals two blind men and a demon-possessed mute man, causing amazement among the crowds but opposition from the Pharisees who accuse Him of demonic power.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Compassion and the Call for Laborers
outline.description: Jesus teaches, preaches, and heals throughout the towns, moved with compassion for the lost, and urges prayer for more workers to gather the plentiful harvest.

application: Trust in Jesus’ authority to forgive sins and bring spiritual and physical healing in your life.
Follow Jesus’ example by showing compassion and reaching out to those considered outcasts or sinners.
Embrace the newness of Christ’s kingdom, being open to His transforming work rather than clinging to old religious traditions.
Pray earnestly for laborers to be sent into the harvest fields to spread the gospel and bring souls to repentance.

keyVerses.text: And, behold, they brought to him a man sick of the palsy, lying on a bed: and Jesus seeing their faith said unto the sick of the palsy; Son, be of good cheer; thy sins be forgiven thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals Jesus’ authority to forgive sins, a divine prerogative, and highlights the importance of faith.

keyVerses.text: But go ye and learn what that meaneth, I will have mercy, and not sacrifice: for I am not come to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus clarifies His mission to call sinners to repentance, emphasizing mercy over ritualistic sacrifice.

keyVerses.text: Then saith he unto his disciples, The harvest truly is plenteous, but the labourers are few; Pray ye therefore the Lord of the harvest, that he will send forth labourers into his harvest.
keyVerses.significance: These verses call believers to recognize the great need for gospel workers and to pray for God’s provision.
